item.title: OpenAI Grows CoreWeave Tie-Up With New $4 Billion Cloud Deal
item.description: CoreWeave Inc. has secured a deal worth as much as $4 billion to provide additional cloud computing capacity to artificial intelligence leader OpenAI, expanding a tie-up between the two firms.
item.dc:creator: Edward Ludlow, Redd Brown

media:content.media:description: CoreWeave Inc. signage in Times Square in New York, US, on Friday, May 9, 2025. After a heavily scaled down initial public offering, CoreWeave Inc. is in discussions to raise about $1.5 billion in debt, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: We Should Know Who's Paying for Geoengineering Experiments
item.description: Funding is growing as rapidly as the public discourse around its research and development, but it’s not a climate-change solution.
item.dc:creator: Lara Williams

media:content.media:description: High expectations.

item.title: Sony Debuts Foldable ‘M6’ Headphones With Better Noise Cancellation
item.description: The $450 WH-1000XM6 are a much-anticipated update to the company’s wireless over-ear model.
item.dc:creator: Dana Wollman

media:content.media:description: Sony’s WH-1000XM6 headphones

item.title: Benioff Buys Stake in Influencer Agency Whalar Group at $400 Million Valuation
item.description: Company represents over 300 TikTok, Instagram and YouTube creators
item.dc:creator: Aisha Counts

media:content.media:description: Marc Benioff, chief executive officer of Salesforce Inc., speaks during a keynote at the 2024 Dreamforce conference in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Sept. 17, 2024. Salesforce is unveiling a pivot in its artificial intelligence strategy this week at its annual Dreamforce conference, now saying that its AI tools can handle tasks without human supervision and changing the way it charges for software.

item.title: Deutsche Telekom Beats Estimates as German Competition Rises
item.description: Deutsche Telekom AG’s first quarter profit topped estimates, demonstrating the resilience of the carrier’s mobile business in its home market of Germany even as competition cut into its broadband subscribers.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Deutsch

media:content.media:description: A sign outside a Deutsche Telekom AG store in Berlin.

item.title: Trump’s Rush to Cut AI Deals in Saudi Arabia and UAE Opens Rift With China Hawks
item.description: President Donald Trump’s flurry of artificial intelligence deals during his tour of the Middle East is opening a rift within his own administration as China hawks grow increasingly concerned the projects are putting US national security and economic interests at risk.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 14: U.S. President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman speak as they arrive during the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) Leaders’ Summit at The Ritz-Carlton on May 14, 2025 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The council addresses regional stability, defense cooperation, and energy policy among Gulf nations. Trump is on a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Senators Revive Bill to Break Big Tech’s Grip on Pentagon Deals
item.description: A bipartisan pair of senators is reviving a bill to break the grip that tech giants like Amazon.com Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Alphabet Inc.’s Google have on the Pentagon’s cloud computing and artificial intelligence contracts.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Davalos

media:content.media:description: The Pentagon in Washington, DC.

item.title: Snoop Dogg Makes Peace With Spotify, Releases New Album on Service
item.description: ‘Iz It a Crime?’ came out Thursday as a surprise to fans
item.dc:creator: Lucas Shaw

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MAY 13: Snoop Dogg attends Snoop Dogg "Iz It A Crime" Movie Album Screening on May 13, 2025 in New York City. (Photo by Johnny Nunez/WireImage) Photographer: Johnny Nunez/WireImage

item.title: Coinbase Says Bribed Workers Leaked Data to Hacker Seeking $20 Million in Ransom
item.description: Coinbase Global Inc. said hackers bribed contractors or employees outside the US to steal sensitive customer data and demanded a $20 million ransom, in one of the most high-profile security breaches of a crypto trading platform.
item.dc:creator: Emily Nicolle

media:content.media:description: The Coinbase website on a smartphone.

item.title: Alibaba Growth Fails to Impress in Dour Note for China Tech
item.description: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.’s quarterly revenue grew a disappointing 7%, reflecting a persistent Chinese consumer malaise that may dog the online commerce leader’s big pivot toward AI.
item.dc:creator: Claire Che, Luz Ding

media:content.media:description: The Alibaba Group headquarters in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: Cisco Shares Gain on Positive Sales Forecast as AI Buoys Demand
item.description: Cisco Systems Inc. shares rallied after the company issued a solid forecast for revenue in the current quarter, a sign the largest seller of networking gear is benefiting from demand for systems using artificial-intelligence technology.
item.dc:creator: Dina Bass

media:content.media:description: Cisco signage outside the company's headquarters in San Jose, California, US, on Tuesday, Nov. 12, 2024. Cisco Systems Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on November 13. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: ‘Grand Theft Auto’ Delay Fails to Dent Take-Two Investor Zeal
item.description: Investors in Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. won’t see the latest Grand Theft Auto VI game hit the shelves this year like previously planned, but that isn’t souring sentiment on the stock.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica

media:content.media:description: Grand Theft Auto VI.

item.title: Salesforce Offers Customers New Ways to Pay for AI Tools
item.description: Salesforce Inc. is unveiling a new pricing model for its AI products and letting customers reallocate spending from traditional software subscriptions to the artificial intelligence tools.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford

media:content.media:description: Salesforce headquarters in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, Nov. 29, 2023. Salesforce released earnings figures on November 29.

item.title: Trump Asks Apple to Stop Moving iPhone Production to India
item.description: President Donald Trump said he’s asked Apple Inc.’s Tim Cook to stop building plants in India to make devices for the US, pushing the iPhone maker to add domestic production as it pivots away from China.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Sankalp Phartiyal

media:content.media:description: iPhone 16 smartphones at an Apple Inc. store in London.

item.title: StanChart-Backed Algbra to Help Gatehouse With UK Accounts
item.description: The UK banking arm of Kuwait’s Gatehouse Financial Group Ltd. is partnering with London-based financial technology firm Algbra Group to provide new digital accounts for overseas residents looking to invest in the UK property market.
item.dc:creator: Aisha S Gani

item.title: EU Says TikTok’s Ad System Breaks Customer Protection Rules
item.description: TikTok Inc. isn’t fulfilling a European Union requirement meant to protect consumers from scam advertisements, putting the company at risk of a fine, the bloc’s executive arm said in a preliminary finding.
item.dc:creator: Amy Thomson

media:content.media:description: The TikTok logo on a smartphone arranged in the Queens borough of New York, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. The Supreme Court signaled it's likely to uphold a law that would ban the popular TikTok social media platform in the US if it isn't sold by its Chinese parent company by Jan. 19. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: Meta Sees a Future Where AI Fills Your Social Needs
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter with reporting and analysis about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Riley Griffin reports from the Meta antitrust trial about the company’s views of its rivals and the future of social networks.
item.dc:creator: Riley Griffin

media:content.media:description: The Meta AI logo on a mobile phone in Brussels, Belgium, on Jan. 26.

item.title: Jack Ma-Backed Ant’s Profit Fell 31% on AI, New Business Costs
item.description: Ant Group Co.’s quarterly profit fell 31% as the firm invested in artificial intelligence and other initiatives to bolster revenue growth.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Yilun Chen

media:content.media:description: Signage for Alipay at an Ant Group Co. office building in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Emirates in Talks with Musk’s SpaceX to Get Starlink on Flights
item.description: Emirates is in discussions with Elon Musk’s SpaceX to overhaul the carrier’s internet service as the world’s largest international airline looks to enhance its in-flight Wi-Fi.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: A Boeing Co. 777-300 aircraft, operated by Emirates, takes off from Dubai International Airport in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Monday, May 18, 2020. Emirates Group is considering plans to cut about 30,000 jobs as the operator of the world’s largest long-haul carrier seeks to reduce costs after the coronavirus pandemic grounded air travel. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Display CEO Resigns, Unveils Job Cuts After Losses Balloon
item.description: Japan Display Inc.’s CEO is stepping down and the company is slashing around half its headcount after it posted fresh losses that extended a seven-year streak.
item.dc:creator: Takashi Mochizuki

media:content.media:description: Close-up of a digital tablet with brain x-ray on screen. Photographer: Teera Konakan/Moment RF

item.title: Shein Lowers Prices to Lure Back US Shoppers After Tariff Cut
item.description: Shein Group Ltd. lowered US retail prices this week after the Trump administration temporarily cut duties on Chinese imports, as the online fashion retailer moves to win back consumers scared away by recent tariff-induced price hikes.
item.dc:creator: Denise Lu, Daniela Wei, Jinshan Hong

item.title: America First Policy Spurs Africa Startups to Seek New Backers
item.description: Oko Finance, a Morgan Stanley-backed startup providing disaster insurance to farmers in Africa, was on track to become profitable this year — until US President Donald Trump’s funding cuts gutted its biggest customer.
item.dc:creator: Moses Mozart Dzawu, Helen Nyambura, Emele Onu

item.title: Xiaomi EV Sales Fall After Deadly Crash, False Advertising Claims
item.description: Xiaomi Corp. electric vehicle sales in China have taken a hit since March after a fatal highway accident and consumer unhappiness around the marketing of one version of its car.
item.dc:creator: Linda Lew, Jessica Sui

media:content.media:description: Xiaomi SU7 Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea to Lift Deposit Insurance Cap First Time in 24 years
item.description: South Korea will double the deposit insurance limit to 100 million won ($71,174) per client from September, raising the cap for the first time in nearly a quarter of a century to boost confidence in the banking system.
item.dc:creator: Whanwoong Choi

item.title: Meta Picks Southeast Asia Veteran to Head Asia-Pacific Region
item.description: Meta Platforms Inc. is elevating its longtime head of Southeast Asia to be its senior-most business executive for the broader Asia-Pacific region, one of its main growth markets.
item.dc:creator: Newley Purnell

item.title: EToro IPO Nets Spark Capital $530 Million Gain From Early Bet
item.description: The venture firm first invested in the Israeli Robinhood competitor 15 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Katie Roof

media:content.media:description: The EToro logo on a smartphone arranged in Dobbs Ferry, New York, U.S., on Saturday, May 22, 2021. Elon Musk continued to toy with the price of Bitcoin Monday, taking to Twitter to indicate support for what he says is an effort by miners to make their operations greener.

item.title: Amazon Cuts 100 From Devices Team in Corporate Jobs Pullback
item.description: Amazon.com Inc. is eliminating about 100 positions from its devices and services division, which works on products including the Alexa voice assistant and Kindle e-reader, highlighting the e-commerce company’s efforts to trim its corporate workforce.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Soper

media:content.media:description: The Amazon logo during an unveiling event in New York, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025. Amazon has rebooted Alexa with artificial intelligence, marking the biggest overhaul of the voice-activated assistant since its introduction over a decade ago. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: What’s at Stake as the US Gives Saudis Access to State-of-the-Art AI Chips
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration has changed the direction of US AI policy toward two oil-rich states in the Middle East. It’s paved the way for Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates to buy chips from Nvidia Corp. and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. that are considered state-of-the-art when it comes to creating and running artificial intelligence software and services. Previously, the US had restrictions on delivering advanced technology to the region as part of broader controls on the sp
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman during the Saudi-US investment forum in Riyadh on May 13.

item.title: CoreWeave Drops as Sped-Up AI Investment Plans Dent Profits
item.description: CoreWeave Inc.’s quarterly profit forecast missed estimates as the company said it was bringing forward some spending to meet customer needs. The shares dropped as much as 11% in post-market trading.
item.dc:creator: Redd Brown

media:content.media:description: CoreWeave Inc. signage in Times Square in New York, US, on Friday, May 9, 2025. After a heavily scaled down initial public offering, CoreWeave Inc. is in discussions to raise about $1.5 billion in debt, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: US Lawmakers Urge Ban on China-Linked Router Maker TP-Link
item.description: Seventeen Republican lawmakers urged the Commerce Department to prohibit further sales of equipment from TP-Link Systems Inc., a Wi-Fi router maker whose links to China have raised concerns and prompted investigations in the US.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Workers on the production line at a TP-Link workshop in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Liang Xu/Xinhua/Getty Images
